description: Guava is a tropical fruit known for its sweet, tangy flavor and high vitamin C content. It is widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions. Guava trees are hardy and adaptable, with a preference for well-drained soils and warm climates.

soil.type: Well-drained loamy soil with organic matter

climate.watering: Water regularly, but avoid waterlogging. Ensure the soil is moist but well-drained, especially during the fruiting stage.

symptoms: Yellowing of leaves, followed by wilting and defoliation.
Dark, water-soaked lesions at the base of stems and roots.
Stunted growth and dieback of young shoots.
Foul smell from rotting roots in severe cases.

background.cause: Fungal disease caused by *Phytophthora* species, which thrive in waterlogged or poorly drained soils.
background.spread_by: Water, contaminated soil, and plant material.

cure: Apply fungicides like Metalaxyl or Fosetyl-Al to control the spread of the disease.
Improve drainage around the root zone to prevent waterlogging.
Prune infected parts of the plant and dispose of them properly.
Avoid over-irrigating and maintain good soil drainage to reduce favorable conditions for the fungus.
diseases.fertilizers: Use phosphorus and potassium-rich fertilizers to help strengthen plant defenses against root rot.
prevention: Ensure proper drainage in the soil to prevent water accumulation around roots.
Use certified disease-free seedlings to prevent initial infection.
Avoid overhead irrigation to keep the soil surface dry and reduce fungal spore dispersal.
Practice crop rotation and do not plant guavas in the same area year after year.

symptoms: Red, rust-like pustules on the underside of leaves.
Yellowing and curling of leaves, followed by defoliation.
Reduced fruit set and poor fruit quality.
Premature leaf drop, weakening the plant.

background.cause: Fungal disease caused by *Puccinia psidii*, which thrives in humid and warm conditions.
background.spread_by: Wind, rain, and contaminated plant material.

cure: Apply fungicides such as Tebuconazole or Propiconazole to control rust infections.
Remove and destroy infected leaves and plant material to reduce fungal spread.
Prune affected branches and leaves to improve air circulation and reduce humidity around the plant.
Spray copper-based fungicides during the early stages of infection.
diseases.fertilizers: Use balanced fertilizers, avoiding excess nitrogen, which may encourage fungal growth.
prevention: Space plants adequately to ensure good airflow and reduce humidity around the foliage.
Remove fallen leaves and plant debris regularly.
Avoid working with wet plants to minimize the spread of spores.
Use resistant guava varieties if available in your region.

symptoms: Small, dark, sunken lesions on the leaves and fruits.
Lesions may coalesce, causing severe leaf deformation.
Blackened fruit spots that result in poor fruit quality and early drop.
Defoliation in severe cases, reducing plant vigor.

background.cause: Fungal disease caused by *Cladosporium psidii*, which thrives in moist, humid conditions.
background.spread_by: Rain, wind, and contaminated plant material.

cure: Apply fungicides like Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil at the onset of symptoms.
Remove and destroy infected leaves and fruits to reduce the spread of spores.
Prune infected branches and maintain proper spacing to improve air circulation.
Spray fungicides regularly, especially during the rainy season or humid periods.
diseases.fertilizers: Use balanced fertilizers with micronutrients to promote healthy plant growth.
prevention: Ensure good spacing between plants to allow airflow and reduce humidity around leaves.
Avoid overhead irrigation to prevent water droplets from spreading fungal spores.
Clean tools and equipment regularly to prevent cross-contamination between plants.

symptoms: Stunted growth and wilting of young plants.
Yellowing of leaves, followed by dieback of branches and roots.
Brown, decayed roots and discolored vascular tissue.
Premature fruit drop and reduced yield.

background.cause: Fungal disease caused by *Ceratocystis fimbriata*, which attacks the roots and vascular system of guava plants.
background.spread_by: Contaminated soil, plant material, and water.

cure: Remove infected plants and destroy them to prevent disease spread.
Apply fungicides such as Azoxystrobin or Thiophanate-methyl to control root rot and vascular infections.
Improve soil drainage and reduce over-watering to prevent the disease.
Disinfect tools and equipment regularly to avoid contamination between plants.
diseases.fertilizers: Use phosphorus and potassium-rich fertilizers to strengthen plant roots and improve resistance to fungal infections.
prevention: Avoid planting guava in waterlogged areas and improve soil drainage.
Use disease-free planting material and avoid planting in previously infected soil.
Practice crop rotation to reduce the buildup of pathogens in the soil.
Maintain good field hygiene by removing fallen leaves and plant debris.

preventive_practices: Use disease-free seedlings and planting material
Ensure good drainage in the soil to prevent waterlogging
Space plants adequately to improve air circulation and reduce humidity
Remove fallen leaves and plant debris regularly to reduce fungal spore buildup
Apply fungicides preventively, especially during humid and rainy conditions
Practice crop rotation to reduce the build-up of soil-borne pathogens
